nodes.title: WEEK 8: Visual system and perception
nodes.description: This node describes some key aspects of Week 8: Visual system.

typeData.textContent: This node describes some key aspects of Week 8, including important background on: (1) the anatomy of the human eye (Elbert Ng); (2) light waves and human perception of colour (Kathleen Deering); and (3) human sensation and perception (Juliana Antepyan).

nodes.title: Waves (Kathleen Deering)
nodes.description: This node describes waves with implications for perception within the visual and auditory systems

nodes.title: Juliana Antepyan - The Importance of Attention in Sensation & Perception
nodes.description: Additional information to the importance of attention in sensation and perception. Includes a definition of key terms, further studies, and consequential implications

typeData.textContent:
Key Definitions:
• Sensation involves the use of sensory receptors and includes the five senses: Vision, hearing (audition), smell (olfaction), taste (gustation), and touch (somatosensation).
• Perception is the way that sensory information is processed, decoded, and consciously experienced, and involves bottom-up processing and top-down processing.
• Inattentional blindness is the failure to notice something due to lack of attention. This perceptual phenomena, along with 'Change blindness', has changed the way that scientists view visual perception.

Examples of Studies:
• The importance of attention is shown in a study by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999):
	○ Participants watched a video of people dressed in black and white uniforms passing basketballs.
	○ Participants were instructed to count the number of times the team in white passed the ball.
	○ Most participants did not notice the person in a gorilla costume that passed through the court.
• In an experiment that coined the term inattentional blindness in 1998 by psychologists Arien Mack and Irvin Rock, participants were presented a small cross briefly on a computer screen for several trials and were asked to judge which arm of the cross was longer.
	○ After several trials, an unexpected object (a brightly colored rectangle) appeared on the screen along with the cross.
	○ Participants often failed to notice the object, even in the centre of their visual field.
	○ In regards to the experiment, Mack stated that she "came away from our studies convinced that there's no conscious perception without attention."

Further Implications:
• It has been questioned whether inattentional blindess reflects a failure of perception or instead represents limitations in memory.
	○ It is possible that unattended objects are consciously perceived, but immediately forgotten.
	○ An example of this is a recent study done by psychologist Cathleen Moore, who showed that though they are not consciously recalled, a certain pattern of dots is able to influence how participants perceive objects to which they are paying attention.
Others argue that it is unlikely that people would notice but quickly forget something as startling as a gorilla playing basketball, and that there are other unconscious factors at work.

Bibliography:
Carpenter, Siri. Sights Unseen. American Psychologist Association. April 2001. Vol 32. No 4.
Openstax. Psychology. Openstax College. February 2014. Vol 9.30
